sols_html:
Since this integral can be solved directly, we try the comparison test instead to prove divergence. Notice that for large \(\displaystyle x\), the integrand behaves like \(\displaystyle 1/x\). Since \(\int_2^\infty 1/x\ dx\) diverges, it will be our goal to show that our integrand is larger than a constant times \(\displaystyle 1/x\).

First, since \(\displaystyle \sin x \geq -1\), we have

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle \frac{x+\sin x}{1+x^2} \geq \frac{x-1}{1+x^2}\end{aligned}\]

Now, for \(\displaystyle x \geq 2\), we have

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle \frac{x-1}{1+x^2} \geq \frac{1}{3x}\end{aligned}\]

To prove this, notice if \(\displaystyle x \geq 2\), then

\[\begin{aligned} x(2x-3) & \geq 2 \cdot 1 \geq 1 \\ 3x^2-3x & \geq x^2 + 1 \\ \frac{x-1}{1+x^2} & \geq \frac{1}{3x}\end{aligned}\]

where in the second line we added \(\displaystyle x^2\) to both sides, and in the third line we divided by \(\displaystyle (3x)(1+x^2) > 0\).

Now, since

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle \int_2^\infty \frac{1}{3x} \ dx = \frac{1}{3} \int_2^\infty \frac{1}{x} \ dx\end{aligned}\]

diverges by p-test, we have that

\[\begin{aligned} \int_2^\infty \frac{x+\sin x}{1+x^2} \ dx &\geq \int_2^\infty \frac{x-1}{1+x^2} \ dx \\ &\geq \int_2^\infty \frac1{3x}\ dx \\ &= \frac{1}{3} \int_2^\infty \frac{1}{x} \ dx > \infty\end{aligned}\]

and hence the original integral diverges by the Comparison Test, as required.
